conclusion: To find the temperature of the gas in state A, use the combination of adiabatic and isothermal processes.
State C has a volume \( V_C = 2 \times 10^{-3} \, \text{m}^3 \), temperature \( T_C = 300 \, \text{K} \), and pressure \( P_C = 5 \times 10^5 \, \text{Pa} \).
From state C to state A is an isothermal process, so the temperature remains constant.
Denote volume and pressure in state A as \( V_A \) and \( P_A \).
State A has a volume \( V_A = 4 \times 10^{-3} \, \text{m}^3 \) and pressure \( P_A = 3 \times 10^5 \, \text{Pa} \).
Use the adiabatic process relationship \( P V^\gamma = \text{constant} \) with \(\gamma = \frac{5}{3}\).
Apply \( P_C V_C^\gamma = P_A V_A^\gamma \) to find \( T_A \).
The temperature of the gas in state A is approximately \( \boxed{228 \, \text{K}} \).
